thread.title: Hornets battle Bluestreaks but fall in four
thread.title_full: Hornets battle Bluestreaks but fall in four

author: MIKE LINVILLE mlinville@hillsdale.net Twitter @mlinvilleHDN
title: Hornets battle Bluestreaks but fall in four
text: Hornets battle Bluestreaks but fall in four Comment Posted Oct. 14, 2015 at 6:55 PM Updated at 6:55 PM Posted Oct. 14, 2015 at 6:55 PM Hillsdale, Mich. HILLSDALE – "A work in progress …' Tuesday night at Hillsdale, versus Lenawee County Athletic Association foe Ida, host Hillsdale was down, but never really out of any match. However, the Hornets still have to get over that hump and learn how to close things out as the Bluestreaks downed Hillsdale 3-1. The Hornets are 2-4 in the conference. "I was impressed. That's the best I've seen us play in a while,' Hornet varsity coach Amy Gramling said."Last week, we kind of got in hole and we fell apart. Tonight, we fought back. That's a good thing. A positive thing for our team." After a back-and-forth beginning to the first set, the Hornets caught Ida at 9-9 and with Madison Jones serving, including a pair of aces, Hillsdale went up 11-9. After a kill by Olivia Nolan andy a tip by Lauren Baker, the Hornets margin was 16-10. Then on one of Janel Kast's 15 kills in the match, Hillsdale's edge was 22-19. However, Hillsdale couldn't close the deal and Ida rallied for a 25-23 win. "We struggled and a couple of times we missed our serve on game-point," Gramling said. "That's mental error we can't make." But it was Hillsdale's turn in the second set, After falling behind 8-4, the Hornets tied the match at 10-10 and ed 14-10 when Emma Shreffler dumped the ball over the net. Hillsdale slowly pulled away, led 20-14 at one point, and then closed things out for a 25-19 win and a tie match at 1-1. However, it was all Ida in set No. 3 as the Bluestreaks built a 16-6 lead. Hillsdale would close within 22-19 paced by a couple of kills by Kast, but Ida won 25-23 taking a 2-1 edge. "Still, we fought back, even in that third set, we fought back," Gramling said. "I was really impressed with the way we chased down balls, how we never gave up, which we have struggled with in the past. To be honest." Then in the fourth and finally set, Ida broke from a 5-5 tie and built leads of 14-7 and 19-12, before and went on to the 25-16 win, and with it the match victory. "Emotionally and mentally we handled that better than we have than in the past," Gramling said.We didn't pull it out, but I was impressed with how we didn't quit, but we still have to work on that tight end of the game stuff." For Hillsdale, Olivia Nolan made made 26 assists, while Shreffler added 10 kills. "Madison Jones, my libero, she made 24 digs and that was huge," Gramling said. "and her serve-receive and passing. She's a real key player for us." Page 2 of 2 - "I'm really impressed with how my team is improving. We're still a young team and I'm hoping we can continue to move forward." On Saturday, the Hornets join almost all of the rest of Hillsdale County's high schools volleyball teams at the Jonesville Invitational, part of the Breast Cancer Awareness activities at Jonesville High School. By MIKE LINVILLE
